post_text: On this VOTING day, we found it fitting to share a special story that included our Class of 2020 end of the year trip to #Selma. After two days of college visits across Atlanta, Steel City scheduled a tour of The Voting Rights Museum and The History of Slavery Museum in Selma, Alabama. The two buildings were on opposite sides, but connected by the Edmund Pettus Bridge. Our students had the opportunity to explore each museum guided by the first hand stories of Reverend Sam Mosteller who was just 11 during the time of Martin Luther King Jr.'s arrival in Selma as an organizer and who led the famous march across the Bridge. Our students after learning, reflecting, and experiencing had the chance to walk over this bridge. Just as the students got to the base of the bridge on what had been a hot, sunny, Alabama June day, the sky opened up and poured down on our students. Instead of turning around and going to the bus, our students marched together over the bridge arm-in-arm, and then ran to the bus to escape the rain. #GetOutAndVote #AncestorsFoughtForThis

post_text: As news of COVID-19 spreads, we are focused on the health and safety in our immediate school community. Below are some updates on how we are preparing for what lies ahead. We continue to stock the building with additional soap, disinfectant wipes and hand sanitizer through this time. If your child or a staff member is sick please make sure to stay home until you are fever free for at least 24 hours. All planned Steel City field trips will be cancelled from now until April 6th including our International Trip to Costa Rica and our Gear and Flame Week field trips. Currently no school days have been cancelled, however, we are keeping a close eye on all recommendations from the Indiana Department of Health and Indiana Department of Education. As of now, we will continue with our normally scheduled Spring Break from Thursday, March 26th through Friday, April 3rd. We will use this time for an intensive deep clean of the building. The safety of our school community is of utmost importance and I will continue to keep everyone in the loop! Thanks, Ms. Kirley
